pullrequest.title: Improvements to gzlog filter and logging performance

content.raw:
So is this the workflow you have in mind?

1. Record a log file with `gazebo -r ...`; it will be compressed and save every time step
2. Run `gzlog echo -z 30 state.log > filteredState.log`, which makes filteredState.log an uncompressed but sparser log file.
3. Play back with `gazebo -p filteredState.log`
content.html:
So is this the workflow you have in mind?

  1. Record a log file with gazebo -r ...; it will be compressed and save every time step
  2. Run gzlog echo -z 30 state.log > filteredState.log, which makes filteredState.log an uncompressed but sparser log file.
  3. Play back with gazebo -p filteredState.log

pullrequest.title: Improvements to gzlog filter and logging performance

content.raw:
I'm having trouble with the state_log test; it seems to hang on StateLogTest.PR2PlaybackZipped. So I was looking at the temporary testing log file `/tmp/gazebo_test/state.log`, and it seems to not give accurate information for the duration and number of steps, since a manual inspection of `gzlog echo` showed that it takes 1000 steps with a duration of 1.0 seconds:
~~~
$ gzlog info /tmp/gazebo_test/state.log 
Log Version:    1.0
Gazebo Version: 1.6.3
Random Seed:    12345
Start:          Apr 17 13 21:01:57.393923519
End:            Apr 17 13 21:01:57.393923519
Duration:       00:00:00.0
Steps:          1
Size:           907.513 KB
Encoding:       bz2
Model Count:    2
~~~
content.html:
I'm having trouble with the state_log test; it seems to hang on StateLogTest.PR2PlaybackZipped. So I was looking at the temporary testing log file /tmp/gazebo_test/state.log, and it seems to not give accurate information for the duration and number of steps, since a manual inspection of gzlog echo showed that it takes 1000 steps with a duration of 1.0 seconds:

$ gzlog info /tmp/gazebo_test/state.log 
Log Version:    1.0
Gazebo Version: 1.6.3
Random Seed:    12345
Start:          Apr 17 13 21:01:57.393923519
End:            Apr 17 13 21:01:57.393923519
Duration:       00:00:00.0
Steps:          1
Size:           907.513 KB
Encoding:       bz2
Model Count:    2

content.raw: This is the tolerance value used in Vector3 and Quaternion. In this case it's equivalent to +/-0.06 degrees. I could decrease the tolerance by an order of magnitude.
content.html: This is the tolerance value used in Vector3 and Quaternion. In this case it's equivalent to +/-0.06 degrees. I could decrease the tolerance by an order of magnitude.
